photo.title: Palacio Barolo

photo.description: Palacio Barolo, Avenida de Mayo, Buenos Aires, Argentina. Ever seen an office building with a lighthouse on top? This building, completed in 1923 (and, at the time of completion, the tallest building in South America), "was designed in accordance with the cosmology of Dante's Divine Comedy", and the lighthouse on the top of the building is apparently visible from Montevideo, Uruguay. I would've looked for it from Montevideo had I known more about the building when I was still in the area. More information here: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Palacio_Barolo

photo.title: Palacio Barolo_Stairs

photo.description: El Palacio Barolo, located at Avenida de Mayo 1370, was built from 1921-1923 for Luis Barolo, an Italian immigrant who made his fortune in knitted fabrics, by Italian architect Mario Palanti. The Palacio Barolo was designed in accordance with the cosmology of Dante's Divine Comedy, motivated by the architect's admiration for Alighieri. Inaugurated on Dante's birthday, the building is separated into three sections--the basement and ground floor represent hell; floors 1-14 are the purgatory; and 15-22 represent heaven. The 22 floors, as well as the 22 offices on each floor, represent the 22 stanzas of the poem's verses. The nine entries to the building and the nine arches in the central hall represent the nine circles of hell. At 100 meters tall--one for each canto in the epic poem--the "eclectic style" building was the tallest building in South America at completion and features a crowning lighthouse that could be seen from Montevideo, Uruguay.
photo.tags: palaciobarolo mariopalanti monserrat buenosaires ciudadautónomadebuenosaires ciudadautonomadebuenosaires argentina southamerica neogothic
photo.title: Buenos Aires - Monserrat: Palacio Barolo
